reviewText:
Remember Sim City? The game where you take an empty landscape, and slowly but surely transform the area, from a small town, to a gigantic Metropolis?

Picture all of that but instead of a landscape, it's a Carribean Island. Instead of turning a small town into a Metropolis, you're turning a third world Banana Republic, into a competent, capable nation, able to compete with the bigger world powers during the Cold War.

This is what Tropico is.


Tropico 4 is the fourth installment, in a line of City Management/Political Play/Strategy games, that has existed since the very early 2000s. Aside from certain notable additions, the major gameplay, and most of the models and graphics, are recycled from Tropico 3. Which, while I kinda wish they did a revamp of models, I understand the sentament. The gameplay isn't broken, and the models are just visual representations of what they are.

There are many additions to this game, some really add something to the game, others are pretty cool and add a bit, and some are just kinda meh.

One of the major gameplay mechanics is Political juggling between Seven Factions (Capitalists, Communists, Religious, Evironmentalists, Militarists, Nationalists, and Loyalists) as well as the Unites States, and The Soviet Union. The seven factions are still around, but now there are three more foreign powers, Europe, China, and The Middle East. Unlike the Soviets and Americans, who will invade you if you're relations with one or the other get's too low, these three won't invade you, as much as remove bonuses you recieve during good relations. Somtimes during your reign on the island, you'll get noticed that something bad happened between one of the nations, and you'll have to pick a side. There are also representatives for the factions. They mostly add two things. First, a face and personality to represent the faction they represent. Second, to provide side objectives during your reign to earn respect if you've lost some. The side objectives go for the Nations too, mostly in the form of sending goods that nation likes, or donating some money to that nation to earn respect.

There three more additions worth talking about, firstly, there is a story driven campaign, a first for the Tropico series. You are Presidente, being mentored by a Generalisimo Santana, in the ways of managing a nation, and growing it Economically, treating your citizens right, knowing when to kick the dog"
date: and overall just staying in power and not getting killed or kicked out of office.\n\nThe second is Imports. Generally speaking

reviewText:
Tropico 4 is a pretty standard city management sim, except it takes place on the islands of Tropico where you are free to be as dictatorial as you want. You may commit election fraud, kill protestors, create a secret police, and embezzle money into your swiss bank account. All that said, I was struck by how incredibly similar this game is to the previous one.

If you own and have played Tropico 3 and you feel like you got about all you could out of that game, there is nothing for you here. If you are new to the series, this is as good a place as any to jump in. Unfortunately this game requires you to register for yet another 3rd party service you will probably rarely ever use unless you are a big Kalypso fan.

Another aspect to mention is that the game is not very clear on how some of the buildings and functionalities work. For instance when you place certain buildings you can see the landscape is shaded. When placing a farm, the greener areas are areas where your crops will have an easier time growing, when placing a police station it shows you areas of high crime in red, etc. But for some buildings it is not clear what the colours are really indicating. For instance, should you try to place a garbage dump close to red areas, which are presumably pollution? I wouldn't think so, because they just concentrate into one spot... so why even show it? Instinctively I would place my garbage dumps away from city areas, and I'm unsure what the indication really does to help. Maybe that isn't the best example but there are others.

Also construction slows down immensely once your town grows into even moderate size. I keep building more and more construction yards but it doesn't seem to help, and some buildings will simply never be built unless they are prioritised.

Thankfully the game is incredibly forgiving so all the issues can largely be overlooked. If you ever are in need of funds foreign powers will simply give you aid, and you'll find in most cases this makes it impossible to 'lose' by running out of money (if it even is possible...).

Overall it's worth a play if you're new to the series, but there isn't a big improvement over the last iteration.

reviewText:
One of the few games that I bought when It came out and payed full price for the dlcs as well.

Its a fun city building game with humor. It is pleasant to look at and you can almost build your city the way you like. Being on tropical island is refreshing.

You are basically a standard Latino dictator (parody of Castro) who has to build up his Island into a prosperous city amidst the Cold war. You can choose to make your government more communist oriented or capitalist. In doing so you get the support from one of the Super powers. Similarly, you get various benefits or disadvantages in your international relations depending on how you run your island.

Farming, industry, tourism, education, transport are some of the many aspects of the economy you'll have to manage in order to keep your islanders fed and happy.

This is only a single player game though. The only thing you can do is upload your city in sort of high scores fashion where other folks can check it out. But for some reason I had trouble doing so.

If you can get it cheap (on sale) then you can easily enjoy it for couple of days at least. Even if you get Tropico 5 when it comes out, some of the content will stay unique as in Tropico 3 like the radio broadcaster/ commentator and music etc.

reviewText:
Now about this game. You start on an Island with the following.
- 1 palace to guard your president
- 1 teamster office to distribute the goods
- 1 construction office to build your buildings
- 1 dock to ship your goods and to bring you immigrants
- a certain amount of money
- random buildings given as bonus.

In this game your goal will be the following
- to survive economically
- to keep the satisfaction level of your peasants at an acceptable level
- to fend of any rebels coups and uprisings against your dictatorship in a non controlable fight
- to keep the diplomatic relationships with the us and the soviet union at a level where they wont invade your island.
- to accomplish the main tasks given by the scenario

I played this game for 200 hours now. And i can say it is a nice game. What is nice about it? I like leveling the stats of my el presidente character. Like to do the game achievements. There are some that i have not finished yet even after 200 hours. And that is because sometimes it is not easy. I played the campain several times. Got 3 stars in every scenario.  With extra missions and Modern times. I think the nicest thing about this game is the fact that everything has a solution. Unlike its predecessor Tropico 3 where you were stuck with high pollution from factories you now have garbage dumps and water treatment plants in Modern times. You have alternative energy sources. You can import goods and smuggle goods. Your island no longer defines what you can do on it but rather your imagination limits the way you play. I will purchase Tropico 5 once i have finished everything in this game and Tropico sells for a 75% or 80% discount.

reviewText:
Tropico 4 is city building simulation game published by Kalypso Media Digital. It is a sequel to the previous game Tropico 3.

Tropico 4 is one of my favorite city building game, it's so fun and feature rich. It's more like island nation simulation game. You can build many things, do many things... in fact many things can happen here. Greatest simulation game I ever play.

Gameplay of Tropico 4 is very rich, and they're so great! Start as a small town in an island on the Caribbean, we begin developing by building new living places such as houses, creating infrastructure and public services such as roads, church, hospital and ♥♥♥♥. Everything needs to be addressed here, the happiness of the people, the economy and industry, even diplomacy with other nation and the two world great superpowers, The USA and the USSR. Failed to address even one of these and bad things will happen, like rebellion, or military coup, or worse an invasion! But managing those problem are not easy too. ♥♥♥♥ happens mate. Volcano could erupt and explodes, tornadoes may attack or even tsunami can invade! But hey! You are the El Presidente right? Anything is possible.

Tropico 4 Graphics are quite decent, while it's not as pretty as SimCity, it's not bad. Still has its own beauty. Performances are great, but some small bug still present in this game, not a big deal though, just some graphical bug with those fisherman.

Tropico 4 are one of best city building simulation out there, with some small humor build into it. I recommend this! Become El Presidente today!

Rating 9/10

reviewText:
Overall rating: 9/10

By far my favourite city-building sim of all time.

I actually bought this game because I had heard a ♥♥♥♥-tonne of ♥♥♥♥ about how awful the new Simcity was, and I was really craving a Simcity-like game. After playing Tropico, I don't think I could go back to playing Simcity ever again.

Tropico is more or less what Simcity would be if it had a nonsensical, but fantastically humorous storyline. You play as El Presidente, ruler of some island, and the game takes you through a bunch of different and ridiculous scenarios. Describing them would spoil the fun of you finding them out on their own. In the meantime, you have to keep everyone happy - be it the religious group, the nationalists or the environmentalists, which often requires a delicate balance in where you spend your hard-earned dollars.

As for the gameplay, the learning curve is just about where you want it to be. You have a lot of leeway in the earlier missions and the objectives are relatively straightforward, whilst the later objectives can be a little frustrating and even unfair. There was one mission in particular where after playing for hours and completing the initial objectives, I was told that the next objective had to be completed by a certain date - this date had already passed, and I instantly failed the objective. I was... miserable, to say the least.

Unfortunately (or fortunately, depending on who you are), once you get the hang of the game and know what you're doing, things become a little bit too easy. Without trying to spoil anything, I'll just say that some forms of income are much easier to obtain than other forms, which creates somewhat of a conundrum - you WANT to diversify your city because it's more fun that way, but it requires more work for it to be successful.

The graphics are pretty standard for a modern game, although the Caribbean-inspired music was stuck in my head for quite some time.

Overall, I'd most definitely recommend this game for anyone that likes city-building simulation games (be it Sim City, Rollercoaster Tycoon, Theme Park, etc).

reviewText:
In short: The only good parts of Tropico 4 is what hasn't changed from Tropico 3. This makes it a good game, but disappointing. I would not recommend this unless Tropico 3: Ultimate Power somehow cost more money than this, which I'd have a hard time believing is going to happen.

This strikes me as a creatively bankrupt sequel, most noticable in how they have adjusted the shaders and bloom to make all the content look different, but 99% of it is the same content as in Tropico 3 Ultimate Power and it now just looks uglier.

Speaking of DLC, there is a lot of it for this time, but none of it seems to offer any improvement to the game. The game as it was in Tropico 3 was already fairly complete in terms of options for its setting, and I would attribute the choice of what DLC to create more on marketing decisions and not creative, design decisions that would actually make the game any better. I have a hard time figuring out why else there is no worthwhile DLC.

One irritating new feature are the advisors. They don't appear to actually have any effect on the running of your empire, their only function is that they unlock the usage of policies. Tropico 3 did not have this requirement, and there aren't any new, valuable policies that would necessitate an increase in start-up cost. All in all this 'feature' is a downside-- it's one more hoop that you must jump through on every single session. If your choice of advisors meant something, this would be one more wrinkle to make every island unique, but as implemented it just makes each island take longer.

Voicework has been redone entirely for this edition of the game, but the lines are all the same. The difference is now the accents and mannerisms are much more muted, much more subtle. Improvement? I guess if you took the voicework in Tropico 3 very seriously and felt it was insensitively broad, then this would be an improvement. Personally I really missed the energetic, light-hearted and boisterous character-line delivery, and the words haven't even changed so if they wanted to be more politically correct this is a half-measure at best; a compromise that pleases no one.

If you've tapped out Tropico 3 and its expansions and just want more missions, then by all means, get this game. If you're wondering which Tropico to get, or want the most value for the dollar, get Tropico 3 + its expansion.

reviewText:
If you haven't played the series yet, and you have any interest in the city-building type of game, it's definitely worth a look.

Compared to a game like SimCity, Tropico is more mission-focused.  Islands have specific resources to exploit or ignore, and the infrastructure required for some industries means it's easier to focus entirely on one or two industries than it is to spread your resources around.  Tourism islands rely upon good press and expensive attractions bleeding visitor wallets dry, while farming or mining and industry can make for a relatively more stable economy (if one subject to the whims of international prices) but also require far more effort put into educating and housing the populace.

Also unlike SimCity, unhappiness is a much greater direct threat to your Presidential persona.  Especially early on, you'll be short on food, housing, healthcare, churches, and schools, and extremely short on resources to fulfil those needs.  In the interim, you've got a rebellion fomenting if you don't jury-rig a working city on the double.  Inversely, like with many of these types of games (like the older Pharaoh or Caeser games) once your miniature city starts working at all, you're in the clear, and there are rarely any real threats.  (Although now natural disasters can strike, as well as things like superpower conflicts, which make for late-game threats that Tropico 3 didn't have.)

You can play any level past completion of the objective, so you can just keep going until you have an island completely packed to the brim with bustling economic activity, and have money coming out the ears, if you so choose.

Tropico 3 is an important comparison to make because... there aren't really that many changes from Tropico 3.  Tropico 3 is cheaper, has the *EXACT SAME ENGINE, GRAPHICS, AND VOICES* and most of the mechanics are unchanged.  You might consider getting 3 first.  The differences are in disasters and mini-quests that pop up mid-mission, which DO keep the game feeling a little fresh, but if you're not certain on the series, but Tropico 3 on sale to test-drive the series.

Tropico 5 is out now, but unless you know you want it, it's probably worth waiting for all the changes that will likely be made to the base game to be made, and play 4 instead until 6 comes out, and 5 is finalized.

reviewText:
Tropico 4 is yet another sequel to Tropico, still being about dictatorship, and a direct sequel of Tropico 3, being almost like expansion pack. Yep, it's like a building sim, but more centered around small populations of Banana republic, so to say. It was released in 2011 by Haemimont and Kalypso, being on PC and Xbox 360. Steam apparently got this version where they added one more sandbox map and some player costumes. In other words, this is probably the best version.

Not much to say technical wide, but the engine was updated and seems to be even more optimized now. I didn't expect it to work better than Tropico 3, so that's great!
Albeit they implented Steam achievements in silly way. It only checks when you startup the game. That means that if you want in-game achievements to be noticed by Steam then you have to restart the game after your session of play.

And well, what can I say. Tropico 4 without any add-ons feels like a mere expansion pack to Tropico 3: Absolute Power. Sure thing, it came out 2 years after the third one. I am not even sure what to write about.

Well, there is now a new campaign which seem to be fun and with humorous characters. Now with proper main story lines. Still given only through text with potraits.
It was still a bit of a drag, so with it being so similar to Tropico 3 I didn't feel like beating it.

There are a few new buildings, like firehouse. Or salt mine, which promises infinite recources.

It still is easy to keep yourself in power and to have money rain on you from indursty. Actually, you can now import recources, making it possible to run pure industry busyness. And if you are tired of waiting for construction workers wasting time with fiesta, then you can now Quick Build construction with money. Which is great, but seeing how money rains on you, it kinda removes a bit more challenge.

Disaster are now better implented. You can now actually watch hurricane wrecking up your plans in real time.

It's nice to be given side-quests by both campaign and by factions.

And now I think I already ran out of any big things to mention.

As for those who never played, this game is about building your island nation, by placing buildings, issuing kinda-dictatorship edicts and keeping all political factions happy. Also, unlike first game, it's very easy to keep in power and keep factions happy, so 3 and 4 are very laid back games. Actually, it's easier to be democratic and honest, then try to be dictator, so forget about this part. Sadly. Still will steal hours of your time.

It's still is a bit more than Tropico 3 with Absolute Power, so newcomers should buy this one. Just watch it, there is one expansion pack and dozens of lazy tiny DLCes.
voteText: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Welcome back to Tropico my friends! Not much has changed since Tropico 3. There are new menus, new caricatures, new voice overs that lay on thick personality and accents. The graphics look the same and feel as if they're directly from Tropico 3. The are new disasters like tornadoes, tsunamis, droughts, and volcanoes. To compliment the disasters there are fire stations to put out the fires and a new weather station. To unlock edicts that help or opress your people, you'll not only need a ministry new to the series, but hire people to run each branch. You'll get to chose from viable candidates, or for a price you can import an expert. Buildings can now import resources. If you have a rum factory, but no sugar farms, you can simply import the sugar. There are also more foreign powers such as China, the UK and the Middle East. They won't donate money like the USA and USSR, but they'll give you goals to accomplish. There are new optional goals that you get by clicking the icons over buildings. New to the series is a quick build that will instantly construct a building for a price.

Tropico 4 is a surprisingly good city builder or rather a 3rd world simulator. It is very different than games like Sim City and Cities XL. Those two games are more macro city builders, where in two or three mouse clicks you can make city blocks where 1,000 people might live. With Tropico 4 and the Tropico series in general, you need to place each building, each road and your island along with the time it takes your construction company to build it. Your entire island might get to be 200 - 500 'Tropicans.'

Each Tropican has needs... Food, religion, job, healthcare, entertainment, safety and so on. The catch is every Tropican's needs have a certain weight to them based on what faction they believe in. Each faction has major and minor demands. The military will want more soldiers, so you need to build an army base. The religious faction will want a church or cathedral. The capitalist party will want privatization or upscale entertainment. The communist party will want you to enable the free public housing edict or have etiquette healthcare.

On top of that, you balance political relations with the USA and USSR. If they get too bad, one of the two will basically take over your country and it will be game over. It is interesting how many ways that you can get game over. The most common way to get a game over is to lose an election. You don't have to have elections even. You're in charge. If you don't want an election, the nationalist party will hate you and your loyalist party will love you. If you opt to have elections, it will be vise versca. People will call for early elections and when you have elections, you can see preliminary results and you can even sway (cheat) elections. Its all at the risk of a party's love.

It is pretty cool having to pick 3 things to make a speech about and then fulfill campaign promises, but its all pretty easy. Winning elections is pretty easy, especially compared to how difficult it was to win any elections in the original Tropico. It was so bad in that game, that it was almost impossible to win an election without stuffing the ballot box.

When citizens hate you, and there will be plenty that do, they will either peacefully protest or become rebels. Once you have enough rebels against you, they will attack your most remote buildings. Your army will then go fight them, but if the rebels outnumber your army, the rebel will win and the buildings will be destroyed. The rebels can attack your palace or flat out assassinate you for a game over.

Tropico has a single player campaign with 20 scenarios that each take an hour or two to complete. You don't just pick scenarios, you unlock them. Each scenario seems to have scenario specific events that only occur in the scenarios. Unlike Tropico 3, I don't get a sense in the scenarios of an ultimate goal I'm striving toward. I feel like I stumble into victory when its least expected. At the start of each scenario you can pick a player character from historical tropican dictators or make your own avatar. You can even make personality traits that will result in pros and cons. It can drastically change your play style if you are incorruptible and never have any crime or have a green thumb and have high farm yields at the cost of low factory production.

Your businesses, mines, farms, and everything requires citizens in them to function and make you money. Every citizen has different education levels that will impact who does what. So you need to build high schools and colleges. Once built, there are options to gear students to military or religion. You can also click vacant positions to hire foreign experts for a price. If you have more businesses than citizens, build an immigration office and let anyone into the country or change it to only let in skilled workers so you keep bums out of your country.

Nothing is done automatically. You place a building, then wait for your teamsters and construction crews to build it. The more crews and personnel you have working, the faster it'll get done. I'm happy with that. Its part of the realism. If there's a building you want developed faster, you can increase or decrease its priority. If its still taking too long, just have your avatar stand next to the building to get it done faster. The fire station works the same way.

The graphics are beautiful and you'll see every Tropican walking around, hopping in their car and driving to locations. The music is nice and very Tropican / Salsa music, but there's very little variety from Tropico 3. A few hours in I was bored with the music. The DJs feel gone for the most part. They're still in the game, but they do interviews with one liners here and there. The voice acting consists of great parodies of stereotypes. They really had fun embellishing on characters with tongue in cheek humor. The game knows you're all powerful and while being a dictator is usually seen as a horrifyingly negative thing, the humor twists it into a silly positive thing.

If you have Tropico 3, play Tropico 3. Tropico 4 is still a great game, but has a ton of DLC and feels like a cash grab with only minor upgrades. The menu feels more cumbersome and click heavy than Tropico 3. The disasters take way too long and it breaks the flow the game has. The quick build feature feels like a good addition that you don't have to use, but sometimes it takes forever for the construction crews to build, even with several construction offices at full capacity.

reviewText:
I completed this game just now and I have to say that I am very satisfied. I don't really play a lot of city builders, but this one was a lot easier to get into compared to other major titles within the genre.

Tropico 4 has a lot of good points such as..

- Expansive wiki & informative community (steam guides, forum guides, articles/tutorials)
- Beautiful Graphics that really convert the game into an immersive experience
- Colorful cast of characters and their representative factions
- Fun custom challenges and expansive DLC

These are only a few things about Tropico 4 that make it a solid city builder. Unfortunately, I have yet to log over 100 hours on this game so any further points would be best commented on by more experienced players.

My only complaint after completing the game 100% is that some of the objective descriptions are pretty vague. I encountered 2 such missions which I had trouble fully understanding mainly due to the lack of objectivity in the text. If you google 'canned goods index tropico 4' then you'll be able to see what I mean.

Anyway, aside from that small thorn on my side, I genuinly had fun with the game. There were a lot of ways to win and even more ways to lose terribly but all of them simply add to the flavor of the game.

I've already gotten Tropico 5 just because of how much I enjoyed this game!

reviewText:
For a game with revolution constantly under the surface, or on its sleeve, Tropico 4 takes a pretty conservative stance to pushing the series forward. Filled with incremental improvements that make it easier and more engaging than ever to fill the role of dictator of a Caribbean island, Tropico 4 never quite takes the steps to fully distinguish itself from the third entry in the series.

For those new to the series, Tropico is a city-builder, where the player needs to balance the needs of citizens in a third world island nation with economic growth through industry and tourism, as well as building up your military for the time when the public gets restless and revolution starts to spread across your island. Along the way, you have to pander to local political factions, try to please the USSR and US to stave off invasions and secure aid, and, in a new addition to Tropico 4, try to work with lesser powers as well, dealing with the EU, China and the Middle East.

This complicated balancing act is aided by a new addition to the game's information screen, which shows what each faction and nation expects of you, and what you're doing to displease them, removing the guessing game of previous installments of Tropico and giving you access to a quick and easy to-do list. In a game with so many factors to balance, changing the focus from guessing what will please others, and making it a matter of balancing your priorities.

Additionally, faction leaders at home and abroad will always be sure to let you know what they want. While many of these missions are natural extensions of your goals, and were probably things you were planning to do anyways, the times when environmentalists demand you build a wind turbine on an island that has no power draw, when the US requests you start producing and exporting oil on an island with no oil deposits, or when lesser powers ask for a loan from a third world country with a GDP of twenty thousand a year, add a bit of a Kafkaesque vibe to the game's events. Fortunately, aside from a lack of favor and bonuses, there's no real downside to ignoring the more insane requests that come your way.

Past the informational upgrades that Tropico 4 provides, there are a fair number of new additions that refine the game, even if they don't revolutionize it. Nearly two dozen buildings give you new options to please tourists and keep your people in line, and new edicts help flesh out your options. On the other hand, the edit system's newest upgrade, requiring a ministry and ministers to enact policy changes, feels a bit like wasted potential. While you appoint islanders, or appoint foreigners, to high government positions, once there, they simply act as edict dispensers. It seems like the game missed a major opportunity for scheming, bootlicking, and potential governmental strife that would have fit in perfectly with the theme of running a tiny Caribbean nation.

Making your dictator is as fun as ever. Setting up El Presidente's background, rise to power, and traits customizes the way you play fairly well, running from a tourist president to a military dictator, to a sweat-shop operator. In fact, the last is better supported than ever before, with the ability to import raw materials to manufacture into finished goods and ship to America. This new addition to Tropico's economic system is one of the most notable changes, even if it's not a very dramatic one.

When it comes time to play the game, unfortunately, the sandbox mode is where it's at. That's not a bad thing by any means, mind you, since it's a hell of a sandbox, and trying to perform the balancing act that the game demands will keep you busy for a while. The downside is that the game's campaign is fairly lackluster. As a huge fan of campaign modes in strategy games, I was pretty deeply disappointed that Tropico 4's ended up being a rather long tutorial, followed by a number of repeating mission objectives and drawn-out scenarios waiting for counters to hit arbitrarily high numbers. The campaign will certainly teach you how to play the game, but with the enhanced data screens and missions provided to you ingame, it would be pretty safe to skip it and get to the meat of the matter.

All told, Tropico 4 is a good game. While it might not have revolutionized the series, it does a good job of fleshing out some of the options that Tropico 3 lacked. For people interested in city-building games who're new to the series, it'll make an excellent starting point, with more intuitive decision-making than ever before. For series veterans, it'll seem more like a standalone expansion than a full sequel, and it might be good to wait for a Steam sale to bring its price down to match. Either way, it's a game that's well worth having.

reviewText:
Tropico 4 is a fun way to casually waste away tens or even hundreds of hours, at minimum.

It's not a hard game, at least for someone used to the strategy genre - and in fact there is no difficulty setting either. The missions are almost impossible to lose. Instead it just takes more time to win if you're less efficient.
If you haven't played the previous installments, there is well plenty enough to explore and keep you busy for quite a while. If you're already familiar with the franchise (I wasn't), then I hear that this installment does not differ very much from Tropico 3 and you might want to treat it, price-wise, more like DLC.

Let me stress that this game is funny. It is riddled with top-notch humour throughout, and the mostly stellar voice acting does justice to the character-specific jokes. I'd even go far enough to call this a good introductory game to the city-building strategy genre: you can easily take your time at every turn, and even if you find the mechanics hard to get around to, the constant jokes should provide a good incentive to stick around.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: Good game but I liked Tropico 3 better
Classic Rating: ★★★☆☆

I do not own any DLC (so far) and I think those might make some difference gameplay wise, so this review is based on vanilla.

Keeping it short, hoping you've already played Tropico at least once, this is a nice game in the series with added challenges and game variations, compared to Tropico 3. What I did like better in Tropico 3 was the more freedom you got: I like having missions and objectives in all the games I play, because it gives me a path to follow and keeps me engaged while progressing but Tropico 4 has too many constraints IMHO. You'll be flooded by requests with almost no time left to organize your island the way you like, so the management aspect of the game really suffers a bit.

Two good points which I'd like to highlight are the commentary, which is really funny to listen to and full translations in several languages which are always welcome to me.

reviewText:
Hello this is el Presidente! Penultimo says this game is very good. You must buy it and build a paradise.
The game is very fun. One of the best city building/economic strategy games I've played.
I've played only campaign, both main game and modern times. I liked both campaigns. Missions are interesting and different mostly. The game is not realistic, but it reflects the factions pretty well. Communists are always unhappy about healthcare and housing quality, religion faction always wants a new church built and faction leader always gets drunk in the pub, nationalist are killing immigrants, capitalists can do everything for money. Same as in real life.
The dialogues and missions are fun and it will make you laugh. There was an earthquake and your mine collapsed and trapped the workers? You paid Chinese experts for the drill which will help to free them? Oh no Presidente the crappy Chinese drill exploded and triggered another earthquake.
You can be good dictator, build a paradise where everyone is happy, has a job with high salary and free housing, people are free, etc. Maybe sometimes they get llama flu, but when you have a perfect healthcare it's not a problem.
Or you could be a ruthless dictator, shooting at the protesters, living in polluted environment, keeping people in poverty, they die from a bad healthcare or starvation, are homeless. Where do their money go then? To your personal Swiss bank account.
The graphics are really nice for a strategy game and performance is very good with everything maxed out on a mid range PC. Music is repetitive but it's not boring, it's not getting old.
I know Tropico 5 is out already, but this one is much cheaper and already has all the DLC released.

reviewText:
Another very solid entry in the Tropico franchise. Easy to grasp city-building with plenty of fun concepts to play around with. Crisp and pleasant graphics and sound really help drive home this game's vacation feel.

Tropico 4 not only has a fun and interesting campaign, but a pretty fun and engaging sandbox mode as well. A lot of the time this genre only seems to be able to deliver one of these things, really enjoy getting both in one solid package here.

If you like... city-builders, light-economic sims, freedom in attacking your objectives, the Caribbean, you'll like this game.

If you always wanted to be a El Presidente" or thought Jim Jones had some good ideas and just sort of messed up the execution - buy this game."

reviewText:
When you were a kid and adults asked you what you wanted to be when you grew up, how did you answer? Doctor? Lawyer? Scientist? Firefighter? Dog groomer?

Unless you said El Presidente, you answered wrong. You had worthless dreams.

I was such a kid, but it wasn't until I played this game that I realized what an unmotivated fool I was. Sure, like anyone I've thought about taking over a country or two, but never as El Presidente. Now I can fulfill a dream I never knew I had—absolute power over a chain of Caribbean islands—without (much of) a risk of Richard Nixon ordering my assassination.

Now when you hear those sirens
Don’t you think it's just a drill
Cause when El Presidente pulls the trigger
He always shoots to kill

reviewText: Never really looked at this game before, but it came on sale and i thought why the hell not and pulled the trigger. I downloaded it and thought I'd give it a quick play..... 10 hours later I was thinking I'm hungry, tired and my wrist hurts and holy ♥♥♥♥ this is addictive. The game is fantastic, i've never wanted to be a dictator before, but this game makes it so appealing. You are initially given a fairly delapidated old island village to bring back to glory whilst building farms and schools and churches all whilst dealing with international diplomacy and factions at home.\nThis is one of the first times I haven't turned the music of in a game, the latino soundtrack compliments the game beautifully and its so upbeat. The graphics are really good when you max it out, you can see every detail of your emerging island and its people. I highly recommend this game, this will add up to many enjoyable hours that make it excellent value, I will be getting Tropico 5 now, thats for sure.

Have the USA get mad at you for building them
Have the USA send warships to you
Be allies with Russia
Discover Aliens
Build a massive Nuclearbomb shelter, just for yourself
Have jets fly through skyscrapers and mountains
Have tornado tear through a shabby, wooden shack, and not have a single twig ripped off of it
BUT Have a tornado tear through a strong, steel, concrete apartment and have it collapse to rubble
Have a tsunami bigger than your island only flip a cargo ship, and spend thousands of $$$ cleaning the oil spill
Build Nuclear warheads to scare USA
Build a space station
Fill in every single gap between your buildings with parks
And much, much more
Then this is the game for you!
11/10

reviewText:
Hola, Amigos! It is I, your humble servant, Presidente, here to tell you about the glorious life that awaits you in Tropico... the Fourth!

I love this game. Love it. Can't even begin to express how much love I have for it. Ask me what my most anticipated game at present is, and it's not the next big AAA experience, nor some indie puzzle darling, heck, part of me might even tell you it's not the games I'm trying to make. My most anticipated video game at present is Tropico 5, and that's entirely due to the strength of its predecessor. This game's steady stream of DLC, which recently ended, always got me amazingly excited, and I always tried to buy them whenever I could. As City builders go, it's accessible in all the right ways. Simple, but not dumb.

First off, it's one of the most chill games I've ever played, not in its attitude, but in mine, while I play it. With Tropico 4, I like to sit back, relax, smile, and play. The game's script and attitude makes me chuckle--it's a humorous game, and one of the funniest titles to have been released in 2011 (has it really been that long?). There are tons of buildings that all work well together, and the new DLC buildings almost all feel as integral to the gameplay as the stuff that came before.

Modern Times, the game's large expansion, was superb, sporting a large campaign that, among other things, involved building a ton of shanties to create a mirror to reflect a giant space laser.

One thing that really makes Tropico 4 great, though, is the way choice and consequence works. Decisions you make early on in the game can prove to have incredibly positive benefits by the game's end. Or, of course, they can hurt you and drag things out. But... it's hard to lose, and that's a good thing. It's not that it's easy to win, it's just simply hard to completely fail the game. I can't even begin to tell you how many times I've hit a negative balance in my account, only to come out swinging with $50,000 and $60,000 balances quickly stacking up after. Winning is fun, and losing's so rare, it's hard to feel bad about.

The game is fun, but hey, you don't have to take my word for it, because there's a demo. Go pick it up. Kick back, relax, and give it a go. Have fun. And then realize that Tropico 4's going to give you a ton more of that, but with even more varied and diverse stuff.

Tropico is yours for the making.

reviewText:
In Tropico 4 you play the part of a carribean dictator trying to develop various islands while under pressure from world super powers, rebel groups, unique terrain and mission limitations, and your own populace. In each mission you'll invariably start out with little more than a palace, a dock where you load and unload goods and immigrants, a few garages, a construction office for making new buildings, a teamster shop for transporting goods, and a handful of basic tier production facilities like farms, a mine, or a logging hut.

It's up to you to decide how you're going to advance your people. Will you take a balanced approach that provides your people with lower tier jobs while you construct churches, health clinics, and apartments? Will you focus on factories and import raw materials? Will you rush for highschools and colleges in order to get electricity and higher tier industry? You're El Presidente, so you decide.

Inevitably you'll find a strategy that works best for you, and I'm pleased to say that there seems to be a decent number of winning" strategies. Crafting this strategy will take some effort
recommended: as you struggle between the competing demands of a tight budget and citizens who have the temerity of wanting basic housing and food.\n\nRegardless of your course in the game
hoursPlayed: I promise you're going to enjoy the charachters. From your woefully inept assistant and groovy hippie chick to the brash generalisimo and sultry teacher - every charachter brings amusing dialogue with suprisingly good (for the genre) delivery.\n\nThe worst thing I can say about Tropico 4 is that it feels like an expansion pack for Tropico 3. That isn't to say there isn't plenty of content and missions
voteText: just that those expecting an engine jump or major changes are going to be dissapointed. Tropico 4 uses the exact same engine (with the exact same limitations) as its predecessor.\n\nStill
helpfulPercent: with the Tropico 4 collector's bundle going on sale regularly
votesHelpful: this is an easy recommend. You'll get tons of enjoyment out of this title if you enjoy this genre."

reviewText: This game is a perfect mix of RTS elements from games like Age of Empires and Stronghold and City builders like Sim City or Cities in Motion. you have the basic population needs found in other city builders where you have to maintain health, food, security, entertainment etc.  as well you need to deal with the political side of ruling which I don't seem much in other games; you need to keep the different factions happy on your own island to avoid getting voted out of office and you need to keep relations with other countries high to ensure trade and extra investments with them. and while trying to balance all that you also have the security of your country to deal with; maintaining a sufficient military force to protect yourself from rebels and angry foreign nations. There are just so many ways you can play this game from a peaceful democratic leader to an evil militaristic dictator.\n\nI have been playing Tropico since the first one came out and it is one of those unique gems that no other game can replace.

reviewText: This is a great game. I randomly bought the collection while it was like 70% off or something and it is one of the best random purchases I have ever made. This game is like a humorous game of Sim City with a story line and campaign. There are loads of things you have to balance like happiness, religion, entertainment, housing, etc. Unlike Sim City, you also have options to be a dictator or a mayor and interact with your subjects (normally to oppress them, but sometimes you do something good). Also, you have to deal with foreign relations (a little shallow, but still fun to balance with everything else). The game gets twice as fun once you are able to get electricity to your island. The dozens of character traits adds to the replay ability. While there is DLC overload with this game (don't get the DLC unless it goes on sale) it is still a great purchase and will allow you live the dream of becoming a mayor/dictator of an island and being able to build it from the ground up.

reviewText:
It's Sim City (one of the good ones) set in a Cold War Banana Republic.

Some actual Pluses and Minuses:
+Not the 2013 SimCity Reboot, but the roads still curve, so it's got EA's offerings beat
+A decent sense of pseudo-political humor and self-parody
+A LONG Campaign that will last dozens of hours and poses some interesting, and ocassionallly bizzare, scenarios
+Interesting Faction and Foreign systems that's integral for things like Elections, Foreign Aid, etc
+Many viable economic paths, from growing subsistence and cash crops to Industry and Tourism
+Things like Education, which could have been phoned in, actually matter and create difficult dilemnas on how to best proceed
-Less of a Sandbox than the best SimCity games
-A bit much for genre newbies to leap into, though far from terrible
-The ocassional random event (read natural disaster") that serves to disrupt the usual flow

I haven't got enough experience with Tropico 3 to compare the two
date: but the above are my impressions of 4 as it sits with a Strategy/Simulation veteran.\n\nConclusion: Great for fans of the genre
recommended: especially those who want something other than a conventional modern city-builder
hoursPlayed: and worth investigating for Simulation newbies if only because while a bit dense at points

reviewText:
It is an interesting campaign where you (El Presidente) try to get money, florusih islands and fend off the great power and other figures. Each scenario are focused on different concepts of the game, such as tourism, mining, how to handle natural disasters or different intial setbacks. That way it does not get boring building the same island again and again.

Not very difficult once you get the basics. It is simple to obtain high respect and income. Even if you screw up, you may be able to get back with the yearly foreign aid.

A negative note is the low speed. You will end up playing 99% of the time at max speed since people move very slowly. Waiting for the builders to reach the construction site becomes very tedious, as well as waiting for the freighter to arrive to sell goods.

About dlcs and modern times. Modern times adds a ton of new misions and even more new buildings. I would recommend buying it. The DLCS are not that good, they just add a not necessary building plus a standalone mission. They are not necessary and I would only acquire if bundled with the expansion or similar.

In fact they did so well designing the game that I think that it should be used as a model in schools to give kids a realistic view on how economics work in conjunction with politics, world views and dealing with the various political and social factions.  If you like city building sims, this game is definately the one to play.

reviewText:
Sasha Baren Cohen starred in the 2012 movie, The Dictator.

Tropico 4, is basically stepping into the life of General Admiral Aladeen.


You play as one dictator from a variety of historical/fictional south american dictators, and set out to create an Tropical Island paradise as you see fit. The game is a sort of mix between the tried and true city building simulator genre made popular by sim city, and strategy games such as Civilization. This is unique, and puts tropico a step higher than other city simulators. The game is also inviting to history buffs as well. Taking place during the cold war, elements such as Military coups, juntas, nuclear proliferation, taiwan's independence, the bikini atoll testing, Nixon, and other people and events are mentioned. The game is quite charming overall, you'll be laughing at several political pundits, witty humor, absurdity of your advisors, and the caracterization of certain ideologies.

But let's cut to the quick.

Tropico is as follows

City sim with heavy political elements
You must juggle relations, and policies, as well as an army and a budget

graphics are decent

The sound is incredible
Lovely  soundtrack, with great voice acting.
Small spanish grammatical errors

The gameplay is fluid, full of replay value, and fun.

9/10 would reccomend.

reviewText:
Tropico is a really interesting series.  In a time when the classic RTS is nearly dead on PC, the Tropico series really stands tall as a remaining vestiage from the old Westwood Studios days.  Now that's not to say that Tropico is a classic PC-styled RTS, because it isn't at all, but it does have that same sort of one-more-game feeling.

Tropico is interesting because you never directly control any of your citizens.  You really only can build things and watch and your people use them or not use them.  That may sound boring but it becomes addictive trying to balance the needs of your citizens, versus the missions that the game presents you with.  You may need to strengthen your economy but your citizens are not well educated enough to work in the factories... do you take the time to educate your citizens or do you invite foreign experts to help out or do you pass a law allowing uneducated to work in the factories even though it adds a large risk to their health and well-being?  These kinds of decisions are commonplace in Tropico.  At its very core I find that Tropico is slightly flawed in that each mission can be won by following a bit of a spreadsheet mentality and carefully crafting the perfect island... but finding that out is half the fun of the game.

Tropico uses an unusual asthetic, the island dictatorship, and combines it with an interesting tweek to traditional RTS roots and the result is pretty damn fun!  It's also a game with excellent humor and many tongue-in-cheek charactures of the cold war era.  I really recommend grabbing the full Tropico 4 game with DLC if you can find it for 30$ or less.  I got well over 60 hours playing through ONLY the campign of 4 and the expansion.  I only started playing custom games after about 60 hours of gametime, so it's well worth the value of your dollar spent.

reviewText:
Having 115 total hours in this game, I can safetly say I 'know' this game. You play as the ruler of a small island during the cold war era. This game is one of my all time favorite games. Not only is it extremely funny (weird radio broadcasts and funny accents) but the population system is very entertaining to look at!

For most reviews I like putting a pros and cons list, so I'll do so now!

Pros:
- Population: Each person is represented by both a model of their little guy and with unique (ish) properties, such as a name, age, job, origin, political views, etc...
- Political system: A bunch of different groups, each with a leader and a relationship with El Presidente.
- Humor: All the main characters (Yes, this is a simulation game with characters!) are humorous!
- Economy: There are several different ways to make money: Industry, foreign relations, exports, tourism, etc...

Cons:
- Gets a bit slow later game (when you get near 1000 population).
- Randomly generated maps are lacking in detail and personality.

All together I give it a 9/10!
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm a big fan of the original Tropico game as well as its odd sequel, but one thing I have to admit: Its a difficult game. Tropico 4, on the other hand, provides better balance. It starts off softly and if you play through the tutorial and the campaign mode, it eases the player in pretty good, yet it gets gradually more difficult as the game progresses. Combined with decent 3D-look, more content, the additional challenges, plenty of gameplay available with campaigns, sandbox and scenarios and a good amount of humor; its a great game, good sequel and a nice alternative for Sim City games.

reviewText:
Tropico is a really interesting series.  In a time when the classic RTS is nearly dead on PC, the Tropico series really stands tall as a remaining vestiage from the old Westwood Studios days.  Now that's not to say that Tropico is a classic PC-styled RTS, because it isn't at all, but it does have that same sort of one-more-game feeling.

Tropico is interesting because you never directly control any of your citizens.  You really only can build things and watch and your people use them or not use them.  That may sound boring but it becomes addictive trying to balance the needs of your citizens, versus the missions that the game presents you with.  You may need to strengthen your economy but your citizens are not well educated enough to work in the factories... do you take the time to educate your citizens or do you invite foreign experts to help out or do you pass a law allowing uneducated to work in the factories even though it adds a large risk to their health and well-being?  These kinds of decisions are commonplace in Tropico.  At its very core I find that Tropico is slightly flawed in that each mission can be won by following a bit of a spreadsheet mentality and carefully crafting the perfect island... but finding that out is half the fun of the game.

Tropico uses an unusual asthetic, the island dictatorship, and combines it with an interesting tweek to traditional RTS roots and the result is pretty damn fun!  It's also a game with excellent humor and many tongue-in-cheek charactures of the cold war era.  I really recommend grabbing the full Tropico 4 game with DLC if you can find it for 30$ or less.  I got well over 60 hours playing through ONLY the campign of 4 and the expansion.  I only started playing custom games after about 60 hours of gametime, so it's well worth the value of your dollar spent.

reviewText:
The 4th edition in the comical Tropico Series. I've only played this and #3 at the time of review, but I can tell you the series is fun, as is this game. Each subsequent game doesn't see many improvements other than in graphics, but that's not what this review is about is it?

Tropico is a city-building game set in the cold war where you create your benevolent, malevolent, or anything in between dictatorship. It focuses on a single island on a time for you to develop, each with different resources and prime strategies to exploit the island. From tourism, to exporting raw materials, to exporting finished goods. Maintain good relations relations with the super-powers or risk invasion. Receive foreign aid from those you are close to, and military protection from those whose ♥♥♥ you kiss. Or create and independent tropico for all of your natives, imported workers, and tourists (or lack thereof) to enjoy!

+The graphics are superb
+The sounds are good
+The controls work just fine
+It contains enough improvements over #3 to be worth the purchase from recurring fans of the series.
+Has enough content to sustain the price.
-Has a really bad marketing strategy. Just look at the DLC list.
-Has some bugs.

If you're new to Tropico then this is as good of a place as any to start. If you're old to the series, this is a huge improvement over everything before it. However as all tropico games before it, even if you make housing free, there's still that damn glitch of people simply refusing to use houses and thus ruining the beauty of your tropical nation. I give this game a 4/5. It's almost perfect for what it is, but needs some bugs ironed out (And this far from release? They never will be). Full price of $20? Totally worth it.

reviewText:
A lot of reviewers for this game seem to feel guilty that they enjoyed it. Not me! This game is for everyone who likes building cities but doesn't like staring at spreadsheets for hours. Yes it's more forgiving than, say, Sim City but being a dictator should come with a few benefits.

The DLC in the bundle really helps add some depth to what would otherwise be a fairly shallow game but shallow or not there's plenty of entertainment value for the price.

Currently $5.99 for the game and all DLC, just buy it.

reviewText:
Tropico 4 is the best city build game i have played.

The reason for this is the replayability.
You get even in base game alot of missions(20) and a skirmish mode.

You useally start out with a small group of people and need to keep your workplace around the amount of people you got(trust me it is very easy to overspent).
But here is where tropico 4 flat out crushes other city builders.
You accauly need to keep your people happy to avoid rebelions, militery coups, etc.
You also got to keep the usa and usser off your back.
You get several buildings to achieve the same goal.
Want to build a booze free island?
you can.
Want to build a island where everyone is always drunk you can.
Want to create a island of mindless minnions.
You can
Want to build a island of inteligent people again you can.
The strenght in the game is it way of thinking.
Here is a problem.
Go fix it.

You can make any kind socialty.
Comunist, capitast, religeus, militerist. etc etc
You can make your own cult island.
Or be a shiny example of free speech that makes the usa look like a dictatorship.

I highly advise this to anyone looking for a great city build game.
I highly disencourge this to anyone who has  an eight second attention span.

reviewText:
Highly recommended if you'd like to play a fun and funny city builder that's equally relaxing and challenging. I enjoyed this game immensely, and I will recommend it to anyone looking for a great game.

Downside: the traffic can get a bit out of control.

Upside: so many.
- Made me laugh a lot.
- The storyline is immersive and makes for interesting situations, just like the randomly generated events and requests that come your way.
- Balancing things out in this game is a very enjoyable challenge and I could not name any major problems in this aspect. It's fun and you have to work for it a little, but you get lost in the gameplay easily and it does not feel like a hassle.
- The music is great, and even though it's a bit repetitive, you just can't get bored of it. It will get you in a good mood :)
- The characters are fantastic. Laughably stereotipical. Love them or hate them, I bet you'll enjoy the dialogues.
- The graphics are not jaw-dropping, but some parts of your island can be truly a sight to behold, and it's up to you to build a beautiful city. It's worth it to zoom in on occasion and just enjoy the view.
- A very interesting glimpse into the world of politics. You don't have to care about it, I'm just saying, it gave me some food for thought and all I did was have tons of fun.

I do not regret a cent or a second I've spent on completing this game.
I'm gonna go achievement hunting now :D
Have fun!

reviewText:
City building and management simulator with a (tongue-in-cheek) twist - you play as dictator of a banana republic, some imaginary Carribean island nation of Tropico. This doesn't automatically make you a malevolent ruler, although the option is very much on the table. But you can be quite a benevolent leader, too, to avoid social unrest and having to create a police/martial law controlled state.

Usually though, you'll play as a mix of both tyrant and quite legitimately democratically elected el presidente, swaying in one way or the other depending on how much actual support you currently have from your population (and there's a whole bunch of factions to appease, with often contradictory goals and beliefs, but you're going to focus on the most numerous ones, with most voters, won't you - politics, yo).

While thematically quite distinct and lighthearted (dousing in cheerful latino music accentuates this), and generally comedic - the game is very much competent at what it does, simulating the needs and wants of your population down to individual people, quite organically punishing you for wrong choices by collapsing your economy and/or throwing you into a bloody civil war.

Campaign makes you go island hopping, trying to build up individual islands of your nation, playing to their individual strenghts, so Tropico is the best nation ever in the entire world... but things of course inevitably but suddenly go south to comedic effects. Campaign missions have their unique predetermined goals and events, however otherwise play mostly like a sandbox game, and there's of course actual sandbox mode as well to keep you rolling.

By now, at least gameplay wise, you'd maybe rather look at Tropico 5 which mixes things a bit more with multiple eras/stages of development, but this doesn't suddenly make Tropico 4 any worse or its campaign(s) no longer distinct.

As for DLC business - there's plenty here in Tropico 4, and you definitely do want Modern Times which is a big expansion with its own campaign and new versions of many buildings. Other DLCs however aren't as crucial, but surely can provide some nice buildings like plantations* for more efficient agriculture or cement factory for quicker construction and resource-free export commodity, and there's always some new trait on your leader to select (this tweaks gameplay in some fashion, like more love from some faction or more efficiency in some area) and some specific mission to reinvigorate your desire to develop one more island rather than going pure sandbox again trying your own goals. It's just that for what they provide, they kind of seem individually quite pricey.

(*sometimes new stuff may imbalance original campaign missions a bit, like I believe there was a mission with an island which was supposed to be agriculturally challenged and even disabled farms for you.. but didn't disable plantations (oversight?) so you could still start growing plants if you desired - not like your people would die of hunger otherwise unless you imported lots of food - you still could've had cattle ranches, it's just the mission was supposed to make you focus solely on industry rather than agriculture or tourism).

reviewText:
One of the few games that I bought when It came out and payed full price for the dlcs as well.

Its a fun city building game with humor. It is pleasant to look at and you can almost build your city the way you like. Being on tropical island is refreshing.

You are basically a standard Latino dictator (parody of Castro) who has to build up his Island into a prosperous city amidst the Cold war. You can choose to make your government more communist oriented or capitalist. In doing so you get the support from one of the Super powers. Similarly, you get various benefits or disadvantages in your international relations depending on how you run your island.

Farming, industry, tourism, education, transport are some of the many aspects of the economy you'll have to manage in order to keep your islanders fed and happy.

This is only a single player game though. The only thing you can do is upload your city in sort of high scores fashion where other folks can check it out. But for some reason I had trouble doing so.

If you can get it cheap (on sale) then you can easily enjoy it for couple of days at least. Even if you get Tropico 5 when it comes out, some of the content will stay unique as in Tropico 3 like the radio broadcaster/ commentator and music etc.

reviewText: Imagine Sim City, but set in a fictional Carribean island during the cold war. Now add eight bickering political factions and five high-and-mighty international powers, each with their own surprisingly intelligent and hilarious writing, and a 20-mission campaign that's proving to be incredibly addictive. While the first few years on your island tend to become repetitive as you log more and more hours, each island presents its own challenges, and the leaders you select (or create) always add their own twist to the mission. Finally, in a major departure from most civ-building games, the end goal isn't to build up a military; instead, your army is but one of the many things you need to take care of, and in certain cases can be completely ignored. Very happy to have paid extra to get this in the Humble Bundle, and will almost definitely get 5 when it comes out.

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic game, love it - it's similar gameplay to games like sim city but without all the annoying glitchy water pipe system, you also have to deal with relationships with foreign countries and factions within your own community e.g. religious, enviromentalists, capitalists etc and try to keep everyone happy, or not... :P

You also have to educate the people within your community to satisfy the jobs you make available whether it be industrial (factories), farming, teaching, doctors,ministers etc or you can always base your income around tourism.


There are many ways of making money on your island, through natural resources such as metals,lumber,fish etc. However, if you lack natural resources on your island you can always import cheap natural resources and make them into more expensive good in your factories such as jewellery and furniture and export them at a greater price. Aswell as the option of developing your island as a 'tourist trap'.


I really enjoy it and would recommend it, I play it for hours straight very happily, lots of fun :D

column21:
heres a few helpful tips:
1. Set up your economy first. Always.
2. Clinics and Churches are more necessary than you may think.
3. I learned this late in my play sessions: Media is suprisingly helpful. You'd be suprised what a single newspaper can do.
4. You DON'T need the DLC to play and have fun.
5. In Vanilla Tropico 4 - power is for ♥♥♥♥♥es. Only make power plants if you are rich or really need them.
6. In Modern Times Tropico 4 - power is for pros. Power is... well
column22:
power.

8. Agriculture is always more stable than industry.

Have fun

reviewText:
I've been a huge fan of Tropico since the 1st game. So much in fact, I rebought the 3rd game on steam just for digital purposes even though it's already installed with a disc. The series is fantastic, about operating your little island republic in quite literally any way you see fit. There are options galore, from being a totalitarian dictator to gracious president, a religious zealot to intellectual know-it-all, and more with factions to go along with them that will generally respect you for your actions towards that.

That said, I'm only recommending this game because it's just easier to get this than Tropico 3 and it's expansion. If you already own tropico 3 and it's absolute power expansion, there really isn't much here. What you do get is some new voice-acted characters and storylines, which are nifty throughout the campaign and during side missions you get during your sandbox games, but as far as down-to-the-core gameplay goes you won't find any differences other than a couple new structures and a new voice actor for El Presidente's avatar.

Regardless of the fact it is so similar to it's predecessor though, the tropico franchise is still unbelievably good as a sim and strategy game with a great sense of humor, and it really shows in this game where the humor factor goes up quite a bit due to that one major addition of the voiced characters. It's not simcity, it's not banished, and it sure as hell isn't Men of War or Company of Heroes, but if you want something that does a really good job of managing to fall somewhere right in the middle of all of those games, Tropico has you covered.

And the 5th game is coming out next week, so here's to hoping it's godlike!

reviewText:
City building and management simulator with a (tongue-in-cheek) twist - you play as dictator of a banana republic, some imaginary Carribean island nation of Tropico. This doesn't automatically make you a malevolent ruler, although the option is very much on the table. But you can be quite a benevolent leader, too, to avoid social unrest and having to create a police/martial law controlled state.

Usually though, you'll play as a mix of both tyrant and quite legitimately democratically elected el presidente, swaying in one way or the other depending on how much actual support you currently have from your population (and there's a whole bunch of factions to appease, with often contradictory goals and beliefs, but you're going to focus on the most numerous ones, with most voters, won't you - politics, yo).

While thematically quite distinct and lighthearted (dousing in cheerful latino music accentuates this), and generally comedic - the game is very much competent at what it does, simulating the needs and wants of your population down to individual people, quite organically punishing you for wrong choices by collapsing your economy and/or throwing you into a bloody civil war.

Campaign makes you go island hopping, trying to build up individual islands of your nation, playing to their individual strenghts, so Tropico is the best nation ever in the entire world... but things of course inevitably but suddenly go south to comedic effects. Campaign missions have their unique predetermined goals and events, however otherwise play mostly like a sandbox game, and there's of course actual sandbox mode as well to keep you rolling.

By now, at least gameplay wise, you'd maybe rather look at Tropico 5 which mixes things a bit more with multiple eras/stages of development, but this doesn't suddenly make Tropico 4 any worse or its campaign(s) no longer distinct.

As for DLC business - there's plenty here in Tropico 4, and you definitely do want Modern Times which is a big expansion with its own campaign and new versions of many buildings. Other DLCs however aren't as crucial, but surely can provide some nice buildings like plantations* for more efficient agriculture or cement factory for quicker construction and resource-free export commodity, and there's always some new trait on your leader to select (this tweaks gameplay in some fashion, like more love from some faction or more efficiency in some area) and some specific mission to reinvigorate your desire to develop one more island rather than going pure sandbox again trying your own goals. It's just that for what they provide, they kind of seem individually quite pricey.

(*sometimes new stuff may imbalance original campaign missions a bit, like I believe there was a mission with an island which was supposed to be agriculturally challenged and even disabled farms for you.. but didn't disable plantations (oversight?) so you could still start growing plants if you desired - not like your people would die of hunger otherwise unless you imported lots of food - you still could've had cattle ranches, it's just the mission was supposed to make you focus solely on industry rather than agriculture or tourism).

reviewText: There's an easy way to recommend this game: did you like Tropico 3? If yes, you'll dig this, if not, pass. This game's called Tropico 4 but it's nominally an expansion pack to Tropico 3, though a large one at that. Tropico is a nation-building game in the vein of the Anno series, though not nearly as in-depth and with a sense of humor. It features a few new buildings and edicts and some new mechanics, as well as an entirely new campaign. A few of the added structures make things a little easier- like the salt mine, a mine that never runs out, and the chemical plant, a factory that requires no input. The mechanic improvements serve to streamline the gameplay and the added buildings are interesting. The campaign is quite good and about 40 hours long, a decent amount of play can be had. There is of course a sandbox mode if all you wish to build is an island. I very much recommend this game if you enjoy city or nation building games.

To me, Tropico 4 has always been more dear than Tropico 3, even though I played Tropico 3 first with the fact that Tropico 4 could be named as Tropico 3.5 to tell the truth. However, what gives Tropico 4 an edge over 3, are following reasons:

Better feedback. I remember playing 3 and sometimes getting confused where I'm going wrong. 4 fixes that very well.
Campaign. It's funny, it's lengthy and overall well done.
DLC. Or more like Modern Times". It's pretty much the main reason how Tropico 4 stands on it's own legs rather than feeling rewarmed 3. Other DLCs are... eh. Unnecessary.
Quests inside of game. They repeat themselves in the end but gives little bit more dynamic in game and goals to keep things interesting.
Small improved things you'll see there and there.
I still recommend getting 4 over 3

reviewText:
For the most part Tropico 4 is one of the first management games I've played in a while. I had a pretty massive gap with the my last really intense period of playing games from this genre involving Rollercoaster Tycoon and Theme Hospital, man those were some great games, then in the last few years I flirted with Football Manager before getting Cities in Motion and Tropico 4. What really drew me into Tropico 4 though is the theme and world that it built. While doing such world building isn't unique in management games, the world that Tropico 4 had built was. I was just really intrigued by the fact that you could attempt to embody some of the worst dictators in human history like Francois Duvalier or become a revolutionary like Fidel Castro or really be anything in between. I don't doubt that the reason behind this draw I felt to the game was my love for history and politics, so I'm pretty sure that anyone who has similar leanings is going to be drawn into the game much the same way I was.

Tropico 4 isn't a game for everyone though. Hell, this entire genre isn't for everyone. At the end of the day the entire management genre is just spread sheet management and its your affinity with the world and theme the developers work on that is the reason you actually engage with it. All I can say for certain is that I really like the game, I enjoyed the use of real dictators, the work that was put into the music and art in the game and the fact that game as a whole doesn't take itself serious with all the characters in the game and its campaign being caricature of various historical figure. But I can definitely see that anyone who has no political or historical interests just won't find this game interesting at all and would lean towards another management game based on their interests.

If you want to read a longer review of the game you can check it out on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/08/tropico-4.html.

reviewText: I suck at this game.  So let's just get that out of the way, I'm TERRIBLE at this game.  But I love it, it's a blast.  Whether I'm dropping a condo onto a shanty town or I'm hiking the prices of medical care through the roof, life as a dictator is sweet.\n\nThere are a ton of missions, each with altering goals but the same game play.  You'll have to please your people (Or don't, if you don't want to win and just think it's fun to play that way.  No harm no foul) if you want to stay in office long term.   It's a great game in a similar style as the city simulations, but with a ton of great humor mixed in.  I found myself regularly grinning and laughing at things I'd hear them say on the radio or to my dictator.

reviewText:
If you like city building games, you are going to love this one.

You can decide what kind of president you are going to be. Are you going to slave your people for that little bit of profit and a filled swiss bank account or are you going to create villa's by the sea? Are you going to bride, kill and sceam your way to the top or are you going to earn de loyalty and devotion from your people? Are you going to give people the rights on gaymarriage, abortion, lower taxes and free education?

The game gives you an option to create your own president, male/female and special skills and handicaps or play as one of the famous presidents.

Really a great game, the DLC Modern Times will let you play with even more buildings and options. This DLC is higly recommended. It gives 12 more scenarios.

reviewerDisplayName: Q A B O O S
reviewText:
Welcome to the fourth installment of the popular 'Tropico' franchise. Highly acclaimed with a ton of rave reviews, but is this game as good as people say? Yes. Yes it is.

If you are new to the Tropico franchise like I was, then here is a very quick rundown of the game:

You are El Presidente, the leader of a small Carribean 'paradise' called Tropico. Your main aim is to transform Tropico, an underdeveloped and practically lifeless bunch of Islands, into a world superpower by any and all means necessary. You will  straight up notice some very funny parallels to the real world as Tropico is basically Cuba, and El Presidente is based off a number of socialist and communist figures such as Fidel Castro and Che Guevera.

Throughout the campaigns in the game you will have total control over Tropico which will see you lead your state onto the international platform for either good, or bad reasons. You will need to balance your popularity with your people by pleasing the various factions present within your society; something that is easier said than done. Similarly, you need to stay on the right side of the world superpowers as the game is based during the Cold War and your decisions will vary your popularity with the United States of America (US), or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). There are other world leaders but they don't threaten to invade you, well, as far as i'm aware anyway. Alongside all of this, you must work to transform Tropico by investing money into things like housing, welfare, food and resources, government, tourism, etc. Make sure you don't blow your budget too badly though because the world superpowers don't like broke countries. Also, prepare for major natural disasters that will kill your people, ruin your buildings and crops.


Some people may read this and say 'This is just a mix of the Sims/Cities mixed with Democracy or something like that'. In a way maybe it is, but here is why I think Tropico is way better. Political corruption is encouraged in the game.

Need to get more products out? Run a sweatshop. Rebels annoying you? Wire tap houses, impose martial law, conscript citizens into your army against their will. Getting too many immigrants and have shacks overunning your beautiful paradise? Force emigration. Faction leader or protesters becoming too popular? Have them eliminated or arrested for herecy. Minister of Foreign Affairs made a bad decision? Fire him and arrest him. . . See what I mean? How does this not sound fun?



If you like being the corrupt leader of Cuba and focusing more on being famous than the wellbeing of your citizens who you can force to never leave a state with poor housing, bad health conditions, slave labour, conscription, propeganda, rebels, frequent natural disasters, and 'accidents' or disappearences happening way too reguarly.. than this is the game for you.

Buy it. Play it. Live it.

TROPICO 4.

reviewText: At first glance it's a simulation city game. And it is. But when you actually play it. It is far more than that.
