That was when it hit me, i could'nt believe myself sitting for 5 hours straight trying to satisfy all the NPC and Factions!

reviewText:
Personally, I LOVE this game! It's pretty challenging on first playing, however the controls arent that difficult and tactics come naturally. I would only really recommend this to people who have played other games like it in the past and enjoyed them (Example: Sim City) If you've never played a game of this genre I wouldn't recommend this as a starting point, I'd probably recommend Sim City.

Character customisation could use a little work, what with the head graphics clipping through hats, hair, accesories. Although, its pretty nice to have the option of not going with the pre-sets. The amount of detailed graphics that have been added, especially where structures are concerned makes this a very beautiful even on low graphical settings.

The general public in this game all have their own personalities" made up of individual thoughts and needs

reviewText:
Not having played any other game in the series, getting into Tropico 4 I was afraid of running face first into a learning curve wall, but was pleasantly surprised by the way the game was designed. It's intuitive and does a good job at explaining the core mechanics without holding your hand whilst talking down to you.

What I mean is that Tropico 4 is extremely accessible. You almost cannot lose unless you overreach something fierce. Even then, you can tell when things aren't working out, and you're more often than not given time to rectify the situation. The difficulty lies in the unique stipulations and events of each individual scenario, which actually switches the gameplay up to the point where you get to work with all your tools and not just do the same build over and over. I appreciate that, because it's a welcome change of pace from a lot of other strategy games where you just find the best" way to play and then repeat until the end credits.

The ambience and tone of the game is spot on for what it goes for
date: keeping it light and humorous. It's chock-full of caricatured and satirized references to real life leaders and personalities
recommended: with plenty of jokes and easter eggs to keeps you entertained even when the gameplay starts getting repetetive and slow.\nGraphically

reviewText:
Tropico 4: Steam Special Edition is the first game from Tropico series I have played. Here are my likes and dislikes:
Pros:
- Great sense of humor (no matter if you are interested in politic related issues or not the humor is great! building descriptions, radio messages, advisors, missions all are really funny - even for an adult player).
- A decent graphic with a very detailed zoom-in option
- 3-scale game speed up option - I usualy play in the fastest game mode
- a wide variety of buildings - a lot of industrial buildings, tourist attractions, housing and social facilities and governmental institutions
- interesting economy and political mechanisms -> as the el-presidente you make very important decisions (concerning economy, defence, external or interial policy, education etc.) and you can see what are the effects of your choices
- factions - citizens in your island are diveded into a few major factions (religious, nationalists, communist etc.). Your job is to make them happy... or make them be quit :)
- a lot of ways you can deal with unhappy citizens - you can bribe one, arrest him/her, arrange accident :) etc.
- Music -> you can't hold your feet calm while playing to this caribbean music :)

Cons:
- a little bit similar development pattern - as the objectives in every mission are different, there is a very similar pattern to complete them. You need a lot of money. You can either develop your industry or invest in tourism. However, once you will find the pattern you like the most you do the same thing in every mission. All over again.
- Bugged mission 18 (however bug doesn't occur always)
- music - at the beginning you really like it... but after some time you discover that there are just 3 or 4 songs.... for hours of playing way too little.
- it is difficult to lose the game - I am in mission 19 and so far I haven't lost one single game (although I needed to restart one mission :P )

Finally, my opinion is... you definately should buy this game. If you enjoy strategy games based on economy and political grounds it is something for you. After hours of playing there is always something new you haven't seen yet. And after all, it is so fun to be El Presidente :P

reviewText: I'm one of those weird gamers who would sometimes rather play a simulation game over a shooter, and if u are like me and your desire for a good sim comes about then well Tropico 4 is your game, I MUST  specify that no.4 is the absolute best of the series, the first too are a lil retro and good ol' classics and No.3 was a great reintroduction to the series but No.4 is where the series has fine tuned everything that you thought in the previous game could use some improvements. At the time of writing this review i only have 13 or so hours game play and i have barely touched the surface of the campaign, the story is so far a mix between hilarious satire and Oh my god how did become so corrupt and why wont the USSR pay more for my corn" stress. In a nut shell Tropico is an amazing change from sim city and the usual bland sim. ...... 9/10 with a cigar"

reviewText: This game had intrigued me with its ads but I wasn't sure if it was worth a buy. Finally I got a good sale on it and was stoked to give it a shot. Sure enough this game is fantastic. Definetely has the same feel as other city building games but with some layers of complexity that feel really nice. Instead of putting you in a world that doesn't really make sense or is obviously fictional they give you something that could actually be plausible. I never knew I would enjoy playing the part of a island dictator but sure enough it's an original enough idea that I have been hooked for hours now. If you are on the fence about this game I would say definetely give it a try. If you enjoy games like Simcity or Banished it felt like a mix of the two with extra polital elements tacked on.

reviewText:
To start off - THIS IS THE BEST CITY BUILDER I HAVE PLAYED.

I purchased this a while back, but didn't play much. After buying SimCity 2013 and playing some of that (and enjoying it for the most part), I decided to return to Tropico 4.

The music in this game is amazing. Having a latin background, the music is really well picked for the game. I love all the options that you have in this game for buildings, laws etc. Gameplay is great, graphics are great, and maps are all very well sized and laid out. Much better than SimCity (map size was really my only complaint in that game).

Anyways, if you like city builders, do yourself a favour and check out Tropico 4, or 3 for that matter. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Personally, I LOVE this game! It's pretty challenging on first playing, however the controls arent that difficult and tactics come naturally. I would only really recommend this to people who have played other games like it in the past and enjoyed them (Example: Sim City) If you've never played a game of this genre I wouldn't recommend this as a starting point, I'd probably recommend Sim City.

Character customisation could use a little work, what with the head graphics clipping through hats, hair, accesories. Although, its pretty nice to have the option of not going with the pre-sets. The amount of detailed graphics that have been added, especially where structures are concerned makes this a very beautiful even on low graphical settings.

The general public in this game all have their own personalities" made up of individual thoughts and needs
date: some needing more of one thing than others. Another nice feature that sits hand in hand with this is that if they do anything wrong
recommended: there are five actions you can take against them
hoursPlayed: avalible at your discretion\n\nAdditionally its nice that your character is actually present on the map

reviewText:
I love a good City builder, This is not. It's Addictive though, It's completely Unrealistic in it's own humorous way, None the less I'd give it 7.5/10

Missions are long especially if you're trying to keep the people happy. High Schools almost seem pointless only because you ALWAYS have to build them at the start or risk the chance of going broke quickly. Like wise with Immigration.

I've spent ten's of hours playing this game over it's short list of campaign missions, Maps are reused quite often but have different goals and set tasks needed which keeps things rolling smoothly.

Overall it's probably one of my more favorite time waster games, Definitely a good 7.5/10.

reviewText:
8.5/10

Tropico 4 is a sim game where you control an island in the carribean. As the supreme ruler, you have power over everything. But don't take this to mean you can do whatever you want. You have to manage relations with the various factions on the island. If you treat them badly, they will make your life difficult. Some may even join the rebels and contend militarily for power. You must do this while keeping funds up and trying to pad your offshore bank account as much as possible.

The game has a robust campaign that's relatively fun to play through. Sandbox is ok, I mainly use it for fooling around and trying self-imposed goals. There are a massive amount of user created challenges. Those are where the true fun comes in. But these things can become boring after time.

It has some DLC. The best bang for your buck would come from Modern Times. Modern Times adds a ton of buildings and edicts. It also has it's own campaigns. The other DLCs are ok, but they don't really warrant the $5 price point. They add traits for your president, a special building, a mission, and some vanity items. Get them on sale.

In all, I would reccommend this for anyone who enjoys sim games and some that don't. It is much easier to get into than some of the others (I'm looking at you Cities XL)

Edit: The soundtrack is also fabulous. Very nice island themed music

reviewText: I was always skeptical when I saw this game on sale or in the shop, during the steam winter sale I finally took the plunge and purchased it. I was wrong to be skeptical. Tropico 4 is fun, vibrant, and doesn't take itself too seriously. You can choose to be a ruthless dictator, a tourism magnate, an oil tycoon, or a ruler for the people, by the people. The choices on your rulership and the comedy from your advisors make the game stand out. So far, I've enjoyed just about every aspect of the game and a play session doesn't last too long. The music is tropical and fun. I can't recommend this game more for civ-building games.

reviewText:
This game is really great and you should buy it.

First, the cons:
- There's a bit of a curve in figuring out exactly what the people think is reasonable (for example, protip: housing prices should be 1/3 of the person's salary, rounded down, and entertainment should be exactly their salary).
- The missions are very scripted and the gameplay very freeform, resulting in occasional basically-guaranteed losses or complete non-challenges after you complete an objective and the next impossible-to-predict-the-first-time-trying scripted event occurs.
- Being a tyrant is really underpowered vs. being totally nice and helpful.

Besides that, this game is packed with wit, charm, and fun. Tropico 3 was just a remake of Tropico 1, but this game really takes strides in perfecting the forumula. Any good sim-builder needs lots of knobs and buttons to fiddle with, and this game has a bunch of them - and best of all, they're generally not packed painfully into drab numerical menus. There are no up and down buttons for employment; you actually click a socket for a worker's face to close it off and limit how many people the building will employ. This and *actually helpful* tooltips (some devs get it wrong, somehow) make the game immediately accessible. You'll have your work cut out for you balancing the desires of the various factions, and who you decide to please and who you decide to push to the brink of rebellion will often depend entirely on the resources of the island and your mission objectives. A huge problem with most games of this genre is the tendency for a single strategy to win every time; while this is still present in Tropico 4 to some degree, the missions are crafted carefully enough, with enough special conditions to disrupt your winning strategies, that it's less of a problem here than in any other game I've ever played in this genre.

The writing in the game is top-notch and if you don't find yourself smirking from time to time at the bald-faced satire, then you need to get your sense of humor checked out. This game finds creative ways to poke fun at cold-war banana republics, stereotypes, popular video games, and more. At no point do you feel guilty for being a big, stupid tyrant, because all the international powers are bigger, stupider, and more tyrannical. This gives a fun sense of empathy to El Presidente despite his self-serving nature, and motivates you to shelter the helpless people of Tropico from the uncaring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on both sides of the iron curtain... and maybe launder some tax money as payment while you're doing them the service.

I can't recommend this game highly enough. I've bought all the DLC and earned every achievement because I can't get enough of El Presidente. If you're actually considering this game enough to be here reading reviews about it, do yourself a favor and go for it.

reviewText: Tropico 4 doesn’t reinvent the wheel but it certainly polishes it up. The gameplay is simple enough to learn but complex enough to keep you occupied.  Disasters, faction challenges, foreign powers and story objectives make the game even more challenging. The game is rife with political and social commentary that may provide a chuckle or two. The soundtrack is enjoyable even though it’s fairly repetitive. It should be noted that the population limit is low compared to other city sims and roads are easily congested due the lack of multiple lane highways. Still, these are only minor frustrations in an otherwise entertaining game nonetheless! Pick up the Modern Times expansion if you can!

reviewText:
Not having played any other game in the series, getting into Tropico 4 I was afraid of running face first into a learning curve wall, but was pleasantly surprised by the way the game was designed. It's intuitive and does a good job at explaining the core mechanics without holding your hand whilst talking down to you.

What I mean is that Tropico 4 is extremely accessible. You almost cannot lose unless you overreach something fierce. Even then, you can tell when things aren't working out, and you're more often than not given time to rectify the situation. The difficulty lies in the unique stipulations and events of each individual scenario, which actually switches the gameplay up to the point where you get to work with all your tools and not just do the same build over and over. I appreciate that, because it's a welcome change of pace from a lot of other strategy games where you just find the best" way to play and then repeat until the end credits.

The ambience and tone of the game is spot on for what it goes for

reviewText:
I have not played Tropico 1 or 2, I started with 3 and loved it. Once again Tropico delivers a fantastic city builder / economic management game and for those of you who have played Tropico 3, you will find that in terms of the interface and the graphics, not a great deal has changed. The graphics are slighty prettier (but then they were pretty good in 3 imho) and there are a couple of tweaks to the interface that might take 30 seconds or so to get used to, but thats about it.

What it does bring however, is more depth in terms of gameplay and a more story orientated campaign to play through. There are a number of new buildings which have been introduced with their own functions, but for me the biggest improvement in the gameplay is the way the scenarios work. When campaign missions are initially presented, it isnt like 3 where you have to hit a specific goal or goals persay, more that in order to reach your goals you will have to fulfill and complete a number of in game missions in order to win the scenario. Along side this are a vast number of other missions that will pop up, which if you complete might award you money, faction respect, foreign power respect etc etc; you get the idea. This makes playing through the campaign (and even doing the sandbox island) a lot more fun.

I have only 2 minor complaints; I wish the stats that you are presented in the almanac could be drilled down into more. I love stats and being able to have a little more depth would be great. The second, is that I miss the radio DJ from Tropico 3 :(

On a final note, I would totally reccomend that anyone buying this (especially if you are coming off the back of Tropico 3) would do well to have a look at one or two of the guides available on steam. When I started I found that I was playing as if it was tropico 3 and not really utilising all the buildings and infrastructre very well. Looking at the guides help me understand certain aspects of the game better and also highlight why certain things I tried didnt work etc.

Anyway, I love this game.

10/10

reviewText:
To start off - THIS IS THE BEST CITY BUILDER I HAVE PLAYED.

I purchased this a while back, but didn't play much. After buying SimCity 2013 and playing some of that (and enjoying it for the most part), I decided to return to Tropico 4.

The music in this game is amazing. Having a latin background, the music is really well picked for the game. I love all the options that you have in this game for buildings, laws etc. Gameplay is great, graphics are great, and maps are all very well sized and laid out. Much better than SimCity (map size was really my only complaint in that game).

Anyways, if you like city builders, do yourself a favour and check out Tropico 4, or 3 for that matter. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Not having played any other game in the series, getting into Tropico 4 I was afraid of running face first into a learning curve wall, but was pleasantly surprised by the way the game was designed. It's intuitive and does a good job at explaining the core mechanics without holding your hand whilst talking down to you.

What I mean is that Tropico 4 is extremely accessible. You almost cannot lose unless you overreach something fierce. Even then, you can tell when things aren't working out, and you're more often than not given time to rectify the situation. The difficulty lies in the unique stipulations and events of each individual scenario, which actually switches the gameplay up to the point where you get to work with all your tools and not just do the same build over and over. I appreciate that, because it's a welcome change of pace from a lot of other strategy games where you just find the best" way to play and then repeat until the end credits.

The ambience and tone of the game is spot on for what it goes for
date: keeping it light and humorous. It's chock-full of caricatured and satirized references to real life leaders and personalities
recommended: with plenty of jokes and easter eggs to keeps you entertained even when the gameplay starts getting repetetive and slow.\nGraphically
hoursPlayed: it's ok without being especially impressive. Thankfully it's not going for impressive

reviewText:
Here from Thailand where Tropico 5 is banned by Thai military junta led by Gen. Prayuth Chan-Ocha who did a coup 3 months ago, I bought Tropico 4 and have played it for a while.
I would like to recommend this game since it let me learn more things about politics than I know. I can actually learn lessons about what a dictatorship can do when it is in power. I learn from this game about what and how authorities try to suppress their people, how it corrupts a country, how it comsumes people's wealth, and what they might do when there is a people fighting against them.
I am an activist trying to spread billboards and flyers as a protest against the junta. I also use online social medias as communication between people who are doing this campaign and I use this game not only just for fun but also a resource of ideas and I thinks I get some ideas for our campaign.

One last thing, please pray for freedom in Thailand. Enough men have died by their soldiers under control of the monarchy.

Thank you...

If you feel the price is right for you can get it and have a little fun with it, but there are others worldbuilder games that offer more replayability.

reviewText:
As much as this game is fun to start with, things can get rather repetitive. The campaign missions provided enough events to hold my attention, aswell as being a reasonable length so I didn't get bored, however after about 15 or so missions I found myself doing the same things over and over when building up the island.

The major thing holding this game back is the number of buildings you can construct. The island you are given is far too large to accomodate creativitly and diversity in the construction of your buildings, as there is simply not enough buildings to do so. I've only purchased the original game and no DLC, so it may improve with those but I feel like the base game should at least have double the constructable buildings it has.

All in all, I've found the game fun, and would recommend it if you're a city builder fan.

reviewText: Two words...Guilty. Pleasure. Buy this and stick it in reserve for a rainy day- it will get you through. Honestly you will never be so satisfied sitting about doing nothing with your life.\n\nYou are thrust into the role of El Presidente <choose your name>, President of Tropico- a group of third world, scum ridden islands prone to violence, crime and communism. Your job? Up to you, as long as you're making money.... Build up the economy, provide your citizens with food and homes, get them on side (legally or otherwise), get them to work mining resources, sell those resources to the world, build relationships with super powers, build an army to fight rebels off while you manipulate the masses, build touristy crap on your island and rob the foreign mob, then stick as much cash into your own swiss account as you can- and try not to kill too many people on the way. Oh, and just for giggles, build loads of statues of yourself.

reviewText:
The most basic question from a lot of people when they look into Tropico 4 is this: Is it any better than Tropico 3?

Short answer, In some ways yes and in other many sad ways nope. The Tropico series for those who haven't played any Tropico games at all is this. You are a Tin Pot Dictator of a small cluster of fictional Islands in the Carribean. You aim is to get rich stuffing as much money as you can into your off shore Swiss Bank Account and try and not get overthrow by the angry factions you have to appease, the people and finally the angry Cold War era Super Powers. Sounds simple right?

But anyways, Tropico 4 versus 3. The general improvements between the two games don't seem massive to be brutally honest. Some of the problems from 3 are still there (triggering Edicts still has no visual effects apart from your bank balance, same graphics and the same damn music) but 4 brings some improvements to the table. It is clear they learnt something from the DLC and Expansion of Tropico 3 as quite a few features have been ported over to the newer game. I'm sure there is  a huge amount of under the hook tweaks and additions that make it a slightly smoother experince from Tropico 3.

For one Tropico 4 has a bit more soul and is a lot more amusing. Instead of that single irritating Radio DJ with the same 6 voice clips El Presidente‎ pretty much shares his palace with his aides and faction heads who bring a new feature to the Tropico table with missions that appease your government, the factions or just a slightly easier way to help fill your bank balance or satisfy your people to some extent. And it isn't just your guys the faceless super powers from the first game have been given faces AND both the EU, China and the Middle East have joined in to squabble for your tiny Islands precious resources. This is a pretty good thing as it also gives you a reason to actually play the Main Campaign that has been tweaked a lot around these new additions. They also make sandbox games a slightly less tedious treck.

There is of course the mandatory couple of new buildings of every type and a couple of new outfits to dress up your Corrupt Carribean Dictator too. And yeah sadly that is it. Of course there is also the suspicious hefty amount of DLC packs with a lot of additional content that should really have been in the game. This game really is more Tropico: The Directors Cut The Electric Phantom Part II than Tropico 4. But hey, they added Twitter with the Facebook Social functions and new achivements if that is your thing!

I sort of wish they made the effort and a DLC that added some new Islands or Music as around the 20 hour mark like with a decent old movie you love to break out every few months to comfort yourself you eventually notice the limited flaws.

So yeah, final word. Pick it up with all the DLC during a sale if you are a big Tropico/Management game fan or want to try something new.

reviewText:
Ever dream of lording over a tropical island fiefdom with a private army at your beck & call and a secret Swiss bank account overflowing with ill-gotten gains? Well, friend, this is the game for you!

Dictatorship for Dummies: SimCity-Can-Suck-It Edition lets poli sci nerds and megalomaniacs with an appreciation for satire turn their islands into rum-soaked banana republics or bungling fascist police states. Regardless of whether you feel you should be a benevolent man of the people or relish in giddy delight as a trigger-happy tyrant mad with power, it's your choice - and that's the beauty of it.

Get it while it's on sale (especially with the Modern Times campaign). It's a steal!

reviewText:
This is the game I wish I'd been playing, for each hour I spent playing the various simcity games - It's this game that really hits the spot on city building genre. Perhaps it's the added elements of being a dictator?

Whatever it may be, this game was brilliant, the campaign (and the add-ons) were fun, engaging and a little interesting too! just playing this actually made me contamplate geo-political issues etc, propbably because of the 'real world' quotes by famous dictators that made me realise that - While I was playing a game and crushing my populous into submission, for some people this was reality.

Scary!

Excellent game - If you're reading the reviews and sat on the fence if you should get this, Just buy it, It's one of the best games I've ever played.

reviewText:
As much as this game is fun to start with, things can get rather repetitive. The campaign missions provided enough events to hold my attention, aswell as being a reasonable length so I didn't get bored, however after about 15 or so missions I found myself doing the same things over and over when building up the island.

The major thing holding this game back is the number of buildings you can construct. The island you are given is far too large to accomodate creativitly and diversity in the construction of your buildings, as there is simply not enough buildings to do so. I've only purchased the original game and no DLC, so it may improve with those but I feel like the base game should at least have double the constructable buildings it has.

All in all, I've found the game fun, and would recommend it if you're a city builder fan.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Two words...Guilty. Pleasure. Buy this and stick it in reserve for a rainy day- it will get you through. Honestly you will never be so satisfied sitting about doing nothing with your life.\n\nYou are thrust into the role of El Presidente <choose your name>, President of Tropico- a group of third world, scum ridden islands prone to violence, crime and communism. Your job? Up to you, as long as you're making money.... Build up the economy, provide your citizens with food and homes, get them on side (legally or otherwise), get them to work mining resources, sell those resources to the world, build relationships with super powers, build an army to fight rebels off while you manipulate the masses, build touristy crap on your island and rob the foreign mob, then stick as much cash into your own swiss account as you can- and try not to kill too many people on the way. Oh, and just for giggles, build loads of statues of yourself.

reviewText: As someone who adores Tropico 3, I felt skeptical about playing this game, since most of the assets are ripped straight from its predescessor, and the mechanics are very similar, although distinctly improved.\nWhat I discovered when I finally got around to playing it, however, is a beautifully silly game. Where Tropico 3 had tossed out puns and occasional tongue-in-cheek exclamations over the radio, Tropico 4 has mostly-voiced campaigns, a suite of comedic characters with hilarious interactions, a genuinely funny radio announcement for a lot of the buildings (which does not play as frustratingly frequently as in 3), and a distinct sense of absurdity in the very structure of the campaign. For instance, one of the campaign missions has a series of voice clips which are direct spoofs of the most interesting man in the world
date: which left me giggling to myself.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY THIS. Don't support bad publisher behavior. Please not that my negative review is not an indictment of the game so much as a warning not to give your money to Kalypso.

I was quite looking forward to playing this game, but after waiting an HOUR to be ALLOWED to, I just don't care anymore. Kalypso requires you to register an account with them in order to play this game. Minor annoyance, right? Except that you need to respond to a verification email after registering before it will let you play. I've been waiting for quite some time now, and no email has come. I can't actually PLAY this game I paid money for. I paid for a splash screen, basically. My logged play time is ALL waiting at the registration screen. That's ridiculous, and Kalypso should be embarrassed.

Look; I understand that sometimes infrastructure slows things down; you're getting a lot of registrations. Here's the thing: I don't care. That's not my problem. You, Kalypso, decided to impliment a half-♥♥♥♥♥ DRM policy for your game. Therefore the honus is on you to make sure your DRM is as non-obstructive as possible.

I really don't even want to play the game at this point. This experience completely soured me on playing the game even if Kalypso does eventually get around to sending me a verification email. I don't want to deal with it anymore. Honestly, Kalypso, this sort of mishandled DRM is what drives people to piracy. Don't worry. I don't pirate games. There are plenty of people who do, though, and I'm willing to bet a cracked copy of your game is MORE functional with LESS hassle than the one I legitimately purchased. That's sad. That's awful. That's a failure on your part, Kalypso, and you have no one to blame but yourself. I will NEVER buy another product from Kalypso Media. I recommend everyone avoid them as well.

ADDENDUM: I recieved my registration email at 7:00 a.m. today (August 18th), nearly a full DAY after I bought the game. Because Steam doesn't offer refunds, I'm going to go ahead and try the game out, since I'm out six bucks either way. But my negative review is going to stay here even if the game turns out to be amazing, because people shouldn't have to jump through hoops to assure the publisher that we definitely, DEFINITELY paid for their game; and if there ARE hoops, they should be FUNCTIONAL.

reviewText: Haemimont and Kalypso really struck gold with this one. Re-labelling Tropico 3 and marketing it as a new game was really brilliant. I'm very glad I had the opportunity to pay for another copy of Tropico 3, since I enjoyed it so much. I also enjoyed paying for the nickel-and-dime DLC that adds a pitiful amount of buildings that took all of five minutes to cobble together in Haemimont's modeling software. This is really the most pathetic cash grab gaming has ever seen.\n\n♥♥♥♥ you Kalypso.

reviewText:
Bad game.

Won't let you play the game without installing a third party DRM client. I should not have to have an additional non-steam game account to play a game I purchased, especially not when the game itself doesn't even tell you that you require a second account. Would have refunded on the spot if Steam let me, will never play a Haemimont Games or Kalypso Media product again, after they have effectively stolen money from me, not letting me use the product I paid for. Only reinstalled the game again so that I could write this review.

It's a shame because I was looking forward to this game, its meant to be really good but I will not support anti-consumer measures like this and I won't risk the rest of my steam library to play a game made by people that think this is acceptable.

reviewText:
Excellent economics, politics, logistics and overall city building simulation featuring very nicely done funny and overly stereotypical characters.

It is true that the basic Tropico 4 is just an improved Tropico 3 which even uses the same engine and mostly the same graphical assets. But the additions are improvements in my oppinion and the things added later with the Modern Times DLC make the game very different from its predecessor. I wouldn't recommend any of the other DLCs unless you buy a whole bundle because the one mission and one building they each provide are barely worth one €uro and most of the added buildings are unbalanced in a way so they just make the game a less difficult.

The simulation is very detailed, so you can actually follow every single person on your island on their daily routes through your cities. Finding out about their needs and their thoughts is actually possible. But most of the times I didn't invest too much time into that and focussed on macro-mechanics. Managing to keep your standings on sane levels with both your factions and foreign powers while at the same time doing what is needed to win the mission can be a hard job sometimes.

After a long time of playing and optimizing my strategies, the worst thing I found in the game is a point in each round, where the tension is finally removed because the economy is working well, money is flowing in and the people just love you. There was barely ever a game in which there appeared any new difficulty after that point. If you just consider this situation a win it all becomes less of a problem.

Another slightly flawed concept seems to be the money in the swiss bank account you can gather through different ways. It makes you have less money available to spend on infrastructure and does not have any other use than improving your game's score. In a future Tropico I hope there is some further use to that. Mechanically sometimes the street building through rocky areas is a bit annoying because you cannot remove the rocks and sometimes need to remove pieces of streets again because there is no angle available anymore to attach a further piece.

Also a very unneccessary annoyance is the additional Kalypso account you need to register to access the game. One would think that the need to have a logged in Steam account would be enough to verify that you own the game. I hope for their next game they realize that annoying their legal customers is not a good way to counter piracy.

Overall the game gave me more than 120 hours of much appreciated gameplay. I damn well recommend buying this, especially as a complete bundle on sale.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent city builder with intrinsic flaws. I love this game, it is a very good city builder sim.

A lot of building types compliment and/or require other buildings, so there is a realistic synergy to how to plan and build a city. For instance you can mine ores and simply sell it. Or you could build factories to refine it and make items out of them and sell those. Most commercial building types have complimentary building types.

It's a very layered game, but easy enough to get into, for novice or experienced city sim player alike.

Downside is that your city will only last for a certain amount of years, but even with that there's usually ample time to develop and play one, and it has a lot of scenario's to play through as well as the ability to create your own scenario's. You can go as long as you want after a scenario ends but eventually cities become very unwieldy.

Overall, a very enjoyable city building sim that touches all the bases; resource management, population, political, commerce and trade, natural disasters. It's the whole package, just served up in nice big scenario's to play through. with lots of inexpensive DLC's introducing new building types and scenario's to experiment with. And if you don't like any of those, create your own scenario with your own set of unique goals.

reviewText: This game as a city builder and government simulation game is a perfect mixture of genres. You build and industrialize a small island in the Caribbean during the cold war times throughout the game the USSR and USA are constantly fighting for your favor a perfect example of the small conflicts of the cold war that don't get too much attention. The characters that appear to you in the game are all very well done caricatures of their home nation or political alignment and are good for a quick laugh when they bring up the issues of the island to you. The game is complex enough for a veteran of these type of games to enjoy it and simple enough for newcomers to have fun too. You can choose from many ways to rule your country, a democracy, a dictatorship, nationalist, communist. the diversity makes this game feel to have no limits and infinite possibilities. I give this game a 9/10 if you want to get into city builder games or civilization type games this is a good stepping stone.

reviewText:
Everyone has at least heard of one game in the highly anticipated, highly thought-of franchise 'Tropico' And, well, there's a damn good reason why.

Let's do a little bit of the story here...
You are El Presidante, and you have just inhabited the island! Sounds easy enough, right? I mean, running an island shouldn't be that hard... right?.. right?! Wrong. This game is hard-as-nails, and it doesn't hide it. You're gonna have to learn to manage your money, look after citizens, control riots and well, just make your island the best it can be, no one wants to visit a dead, deserted island.

If you're a fan of city builders and amazing music, get this game!
9/10

reviewText:
The Tropico series is probably my favorite of the genre, and that's saying a lot.  It takes a while to get acclimated to the rules of running your own island (how rent/wages work, etc.), but is a lot of fun once you get a handle on what you're doing.  The campaign is fairly lengthy though I'm not a fan of the timed quests you'll enconter from time to tim.  Luckily, there's a sandbox mode that eliminates the pressures of the campaign.  Whether it be exports or tourism, your main goal is to keep your bank full whilst keeping your Tropicans happy.  Tropico 3 is almost identical in playstyle, so pick that up for cheaper to see if this is something you'd enjoy.

reviewText:
It's a nice, entertaining game. Humor is fine but close to childish.

Cons:
-Game economy unbalanced. Choosing for industry is always more profitable than the tourist track.
-Once you have developed a winning strategy, it's applicable to literally every level.
-Relatively little variety in the levels and objectives.
-Game play, especially in the beginning is too slow. I always put the game on its fastest speed, but still it takes quite a while before the economy takes off.

reviewText:
A surprisingly good game!
I was never a tremendous fan of Sim City, but i do like the genre.
This is actually the second game lately i uninstall because it takes up waaay to much of my time. I've spent nearly 50 hours on it and i'm not even halfway done with the campaign.

It does get a bit repetitive after 30 hours and you kind of want more buildings and more of everything really. But it's very addictive despite this. There is ofcourse DLC out there to fix this if you want too.

I can highly reccomend Tropico if you have the time for it and like these kinds of games.

I wonder if i will play Tropico5...?

reviewText:
It's a nice, entertaining game. Humor is fine but close to childish.

Cons:
-Game economy unbalanced. Choosing for industry is always more profitable than the tourist track.
-Once you have developed a winning strategy, it's applicable to literally every level.
-Relatively little variety in the levels and objectives.
-Game play, especially in the beginning is too slow. I always put the game on its fastest speed, but still it takes quite a while before the economy takes off.

reviewText:
This game is the best city building simulator - it may seem cartoonish at first, but the mechanics are anything but.

Immerse yourself fully in it as you bring a poor and undeveloped but resource rich(or poor) country to become and economic powerhouse while balancing the needs of the many against the needs of the few, and of course, the foreign powers.

Or - you could just go full hitler and shoot anyone who does'nt like you. It's all up to you!

reviewText:
With over 700 hours of game play, I personally think this game is well worth the money.
There is plenty to challenge you, and many ways to go about completing objectives, or simply set yoruown and play how you like best.
I have played the other 3 Tropico's and this is so far the best, it takes nothing away from the orignal base of the game, and adds a lot with the DLC's.
Now having completed all acheivements for this on, I look forward to 5.
